newsitem.title: FRANCE: French parliament committee adopts sex crime bill.
newsitem.headline: French parliament committee adopts sex crime bill.

text.p: A French parliamentary committee adopted a bill to reinforce existing legislation punishing sex crimes and the dissemination of pornography on Wednesday.
If finally approved, the legislation would force offenders to undergo treatment with the aim of preventing recidivism. It would also deprive sex offenders of routine prison sentence reductions.

France is in the grip of a wave of concern over sex crimes against children in the aftermath of high profile cases in Belgium and France, including the rape and strangulation last summer of 13-year-old British schoolgirl Caroline Dickinson while on a trip to France.
The bill, presented to the national assembly's (lower house) laws committee by Justice Minister Jacques Toubon, will be examined by the full assembly in a first reading from April 23.
It would establish a national database of information to make it easier to identify and find sexual offenders.

Adopted by the committee with many amendments increasing the severity of the centre-right government's original proposal, it stipulates a life sentence for rapists who murder or torture their victims, whatever their age.
Existing legislation demands a life sentence only when the victim is under 15. The bill would also provide harsher financial penalties for disseminating child pornography.
It would prohibit the establishment or force the closure of sex shops within 500 metres of schools, playgrounds or cultural centres.
